awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Elucidating the Drivers and Consequences of Changes in Atmospheric Rivers from the Last Glacial Maximum to the Present Day
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to investigate the response of atmospheric rivers (ARs) to changes in the mean climate state and radiative forcing. This will be accomplished using a new set of paleoclimate simulations from the Community Earth System Model (CESM2) with the goal to understand the processes that drive past, present and future ARs responses, and evaluate their impact on regional hydroclimates and ecosystems. The researchers plan to conduct eight different experiments with the CESM2 in which ice sheets, orbital configurations, meltwater fluxes and carbon dioxide concentrations will be varied independently since the last glacial maximum. An ARs tracking algorithm will be implemented to objectively identify ARs across climate states and then used to quantify the distribution, frequency, intensity, and seasonal character of ARs changes and their impact on precipitation. The project is organized about three specific objectives: 1) develop a robust AR tracking algorithm for use in climate change studies; 2) understand the relationships between ARs and climate system forcings; and 3) quantify the contribution of AR changes to regional hydroclimate over the last glacial-interglacial transition. 

The potential Broader Impacts include a better understanding of the role of ARs within the climate system. An international collaboration is planned to conduct an official Atmospheric River Tracking Method Intercomparison activity with the resulting AR catalogues being archived and made publicly available. 

The project supports the training of a graduate student and a Postdoctoral scholar. In addition, a professional development workshop for regional high school teachers will be organized as part of an ongoing program at the University of Massachusetts Lowell. A set of modules centered on the physics of the climate system and the interdisciplinary applications of climate science will be developed and made available to the workshop participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the response of the atmospheric branch of the water cycle, and atmospheric rivers specifically, to changing climate forcings since the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM; 21,000 years ago).

A major outcome of this project was the creation of a large dataset comprising output from ten simulations with the Community Earth System Model (CESM), run specifically to address our science questions. These included both realistic and more idealized scenarios incorporating the following climate forcings: lower atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, changing land ice sheets (both albedo and height), changing seasonality associated with variations of Earth’s orbit around the Sun, and pulses of meltwater into the North Atlantic from melting ice sheets. We ran 100 years of each simulation and archived data including a subset at sub-daily scales to allow us to examine weather-scale phenomena and statistics like extreme precipitation.

We also developed a new algorithm to detect atmospheric rivers in climate datasets, which is agnostic to climate state and therefore applicable to climate change studies. This enables like-for-like comparisons of atmospheric rivers between starkly different climate regimes, such as the modern climate versus that of the LGM. We validated this algorithm with the modern climate, and then applied it to our various new simulations of past climate states, both realistic and idealized, to assess to behavior of atmospheric rivers under varying conditions. The algorithm has been compared to other such detection tools, and its results have been published in papers under the aegis of the Atmospheric River Tracking Method Intercomparison Project (ARTMIP).

Our principal results, which have been published, are that: 1) Atmospheric river characteristics respond to changes in orbital forcing (seasonality), and since the Holocene ARs have weakened and moved poleward, explaining some signals from paleoclimate proxy records; 2) ARs are sensitive to changes in atmospheric temperature and the presence/absence of large ice sheets on the mid-latitude continents, and as such ARs were less frequent and produced less precipitation at the LGM, except in three key regions—southwestern North America, Iberia, and Patagonia—associated with frequent AR landfalls in the modern climate; and 3) Despite their overall weaker contributions to the hydrologic cycle at the LGM, ARs were important in the surface mass balance of the LGM ice sheets, especially along their margins, because they brought warm temperatures and rain, creating conditions for ice sheet melting.

Under this project, we also enabled and organized an ARTMIP “Tier-2” activity to investigate the uncertainty of AR science under paleoclimate conditions using algorithms from across the AR science community. This was enabled by our new simulations, which were shared with participating ARTMIP collaborators, and the analysis of the resulting AR detection catalogs is ongoing. Separately, this project funded three professional development workshops for K-12 teachers on teaching climate science in the classroom, hosted by the University of Massachusetts Lowell and held virtually to enable wide participation (more than 50 teachers from across New England participated). Finally, the project overall supported the education and career development of a postgraduate student and two postdoctoral researchers at Yale University, as well as one graduate student at UMass Lowell.
